ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to formulate words and sentences into my personal voice. I felt like I dug deep for personal essays.
I learned how to write different types of essays and effectively communicate a point under a given word count.
How to edit rough drafts.
I feel that my writing grew a lot and I learned a lot about different styles of writing and the importance of structure.
I got valuable practice writing personal essays and reading texts that helped inspire and shape my own writing.
Learning about writing styles and techniques from published essays, and writing and revising personal non-fiction essays using these techniques.

Drafting: steps of accumulating and narrowing down ideas
Editing: walking through my work many times and rereading from different angles
How to read other people's work and leave productive comments
How to zoom out and evaluate the purpose of the piece overall

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Loved everything about it. Pace was a bit fast sometimes, the turnaround on essays was quick, but the revision process allowed for improvements on drafts.

I think the essays we read were great, but I think they would be even better if we focused more on the writing tactics the authors used (that could be applied to our own writing) rather than the content of the essays.
I wish the reading discussions were more student lead.

I think the strengths of the course was the workload not being too much and every piece of homework served a purpose. I think a weakness is that the turn around time on essays were very quick and I felt like I had a day to write my first draft.

This is a great writing course! I liked the pacing of it for a summer class -- there are writing assignments due every week, but they're fairly manageable and you get a LOT of useful feedback on each one. The reading list is great, although class discussions do depend on student participation, so don't be afraid to speak up. Dean Hill and Prof. McGowan are amazing teachers and are incredibly enthusiastic about their work.

The seminar format and weekly workshops in the course made it very engaging, and having feedback for drafts before the final submission is very helpful for finding strength and weaknesses in the drafts. The pacing is pretty quick so it can be hard to get enough revisions in to make it exactly to one's liking, but it is certainly manageable.

Well organized
High student engagement
Great professors

Could improve: readings could be all in the same pdf format and easier to access

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. Take a course that shows you how to find your voice. It is satisfying finding what works for you.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I feel like I learned a lot about writing clearly and concisely (which is a good life skill!)
yes because I learned how to write better
I would recommend this course because the class is engaging and the essay topics were fun to write.

Yes! If you have the chance to take this over the summer with Dean Hill and you haven't taken English 120 before, it's a great opportunity. Your writing will improve immensely and you'll gain more confidence about personal writing.
Yes, if you want to do any type of essay writing or just want to get an opportunity to write about yourself.

Great for a summer course
Moved at a nice speed but also never felt way too rushed
